Senator Specter also asked Judge Roberts about his views on privacy.
How does that fit into this discussion?

Well, the Roe vs. Wade case cited a right to privacy as the basis for it, so one of the minuets we've gone through in past confirmation hearings is that senators don't want to say, `Do you support Roe vs. Wade?
and so they say, `Do you support the right to privacy?
And Roberts said very clearly he did think there was a right to personal privacy in the liberty clause of the 14th Amendment.

And that, again, I think, tells you something but not everything, 'cause I believe Clarence Thomas said something like that as well; that is, he thinks there is a right to privacy, but then eight or nine months later, he turned around and voted to overturn Roe vs. Wade.
My question--I know that George Bush has stated several times that he wanted a strict constitutionalist judge.

What is meant by strict constitutionality, David Savage?
Well, it's a good question.
I'm not sure George Bush would even know the answer to that question.
I assume when he uses the phrase `strict constructionist,' which is one of the phrases he's used--Richard Nixon used that--that means basically interpret the Constitution sort of close to its words.
Don't be too expansive; don't go off the deep end.
But I don't think it--I don't think even people who use that phrase to the extent that they think about it really mean let's go back to, you know, 1789 or whatever and roll back everything.
They mean sort of going forward, interpret the Constitution strictly by its words.
Don't go off--you know, don't make up whole new principles and doctrines.

I thought it was an interesting exchange, too, Lynn, and he didn't get much.

I thought he asked a fairly simple question, which is, if Congress has the power to declare war, which they do--the commander in chief then carries it out.
If Congress says, `As of September 1st, we want to end this war,' doesn't that mean the war ends on September 1st?
And Roberts said, `No, I really can't answer that question.

And there has been sort of a conservative doctrine that shows up in a number of places, including some of the memos written, the so-called torture memos, where lawyers have basically argued that the commander in chief--once a war begins, it's entirely in his prerogative and Congress can't interfere.

And I would have thought Roberts would have said something like, `Yes, Senator, that's just obvious or just a truism that if Congress can pass a law overriding the president's veto and say the war ends, then the war ends.
